poem:
Corrections

From the press, echoes of human error,
Modi wears the wrong crown in their haste.
Baker's title, like dust disturbed,
whispers of eternity misjudged.
Ink and oversight, the humble dance
of permanence and fragile chance,
each smudge a testament to our frailty,
each line a fleeting grasp for clarity.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • We incorrectly referred to Narendra Modi as India’s president, rather than prime minister (‘A bittersweet pill’: Asian pride in Sunak – but also disappointment, 8 July, p12). This error was in our print edition only. • An editing error meant Norman Baker was described as a “former” privy counsellor in a note below his published letter (Palace visit proceeds, 12 July, Journal, p5). Privy counsellors are appointed for life. • Other". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
